title: Electrostatics - charged balloon sticks to door

content.question: A balloon is rubbed on a wool sweater, transferring electrons to the balloon. The balloon is then touched to a nearby neutral wooden door and sticks to the door. Which of the following is a correct justification for why the balloon remains stuck to the door as it slides down to the ground?

choices.label: The molecules in the door become polarized, with the positively charged end closer to the balloon causing a net attraction.
The normal forces from the balloon and the door combine creating a net upward normal force to balance the force of gravity.
When the balloon touches the door, some of the electrons from the balloon transfer to the door.
The coefficient of static friction between rubber (the balloon) and wood is large and holds the balloon onto the door regardless of charge.

content.answer: The molecules in the door become polarized, with the positively charged end closer to the balloon causing a net attraction.
